Text: Rewards

■MGF■ MGF, or Manderville Gold Saucer Fame, is awarded to all Blunderville challengers after a show has concluded. MGF is calculated based on your final rank in the show. ■Exchanging MGF■ MGF can be exchanged in Blunderville Square for exclusive rewards. ■Viewing Your MGF■ You may view the MGF currently in your possession by speaking with the MGF trader. Up to 10,000 MGF can be held at a time.
Overview

A special HUD layout will display in Blunderville and Blunderville Square, indicating your progress in the stage you are currently on. 

The Blunderville HUD can only be adjusted in Blunderville and Blunderville Square. Select HUD Layout from the System menu, or unlock and adjust the HUD manually.
HUD Guide

1. Indicates the stage's objective.

2. Indicates the number of crystals successfully carried and the number of crystals needed to qualify for the next round in the Saucery Siege stage.

3. Indicates the number of participants who have qualified for the next stage. In the Gold Swiveller stage, the number of eliminated players will also be displayed.

4. Indicates time remaining to complete the stage.
Spectator HUD Guide

1. Allows you to spectate from specific locations on the stage.

2. Allows you to leave the show if you have already been eliminated.

3. Indicates whether you have been qualified or eliminated from the stage.

Authorization
A variety of different features exist to help you find the perfect look for your character. This guide explains how each of these customization options function.

Glamours are a means of projecting the appearance of one piece of equipment onto another. This is a reversible effect which can be redone any number of times. Casting glamours requires catalysts known as glamour prisms, with one prism being consumed per cast.

To cast a glamour, select Character in the main menu and open the Actions & Traits window, then select the Cast Glamour action under the General tab. You can also use this action from the subcommand menu of the item you wish to glamour. From the Cast Glamour window, choose the base item, then select the glamour you wish to cast from the list of available items.
The presence of a glamour is indicated by a symbol in the upper right corner of the item icon.
Additionally, the item help window will display the name of the original item followed by the name of the glamoured item in alternating sequence.

Glamour prisms can be purchased from the market board, obtained from Grand Company quartermasters, or crafted using recipes learned from glamour prism recipe tomes. Glamour prism recipe tomes can be purchased from Goberin in western Thanalan (X:12.1 Y:15.0) or Tataroga in Mor Dhona (X:22.1 Y:6.7) after completing the quest “Absolutely Glamourous” in western Thanalan (X:12.6 Y:14.3).

Restoring a glamoured item to its original appearance requires the use of glamour dispellers, which are available for purchase from the market boards or certain vendors. From the Cast Glamour window, select the glamoured item on the left, then select Remove on the right. This action will consume a glamour dispeller.

You will not be able to cast a glamour if: 1. The base item's job level requirement is lower than that of the glamour cast. Example: Level 100 gear cannot be glamoured onto gear equippable at levels 1 through 99. ※Unaffected by item level (IL). 2. The base item's class or role requirement is not compatible with that of the glamour cast. Example: Tank-specific gear cannot be glamoured onto healer-specific gear.

Some glamours will only display as long as the character's level, class, race, and gender meet the requirements.
Example: If a job-specific glamour is applied, the effect will no longer display when the character switches to a different job.

Gear can be rendered invisible when glamoured with emperor's new items of the same gear category. These invisible items can be purchased from Goberin in western Thanalan (X:12.1 Y:15.0) or Tataroga in Mor Dhona (X:22.1 Y:6.7) after completing the quest “Absolutely Glamourous” in western Thanalan (X:12.6 Y:14.3).
While visiting an inn room, items stored in the armoire and glamour dresser can be glamoured onto gear without needing to withdraw them. This action will not consume a glamour prism.

While your retainer is summoned, select Cast Glamours from the retainer menu to apply glamours to their equipment or any other gear in their possession. You may also use their gear to apply glamours to your own.

You can also cast glamours onto your adventurer squadron members, provided they are at least level 51. Select the Outfit icon, then select Apply Glamours. You may use the items stored in your armoire and glamour dresser as well as your inventory.

Glamour dressers are available in inn rooms and Grand Company barracks, and can be used to store equipment as glamours, up to the dresser's maximum capacity. ※Some relic weapons cannot be stored. The initial deposit consumes one glamour prism per item, but stored gear can be projected onto your equipment as many times as you like at no cost. If you wish to equip a stored item directly, you may retrieve it from the glamour dresser to restore it to its original form.

To determine whether a given item can be stored in the glamour dresser, navigate to the item help window. If the glamour dresser icon in the upper right corner is lit up, the item can be stored.

※A “+” mark indicates the item can be used as part of an outfit glamour.

Open the glamour dresser to access the Glamour Creation window, browse different gear categories, and select an item from your inventory or Armoury Chest. Gear with condition below 100% cannot be stored. Placing an item into the glamour dresser will reset its spiritbond to 0%, as well as remove customization including glamours, crests, signatures, materia, and most aetherial bonuses. The item will also be bound to you upon removal. ※Each item stored will cost one glamour prism. ※Dyes applied to the item will not be reset.

Once an item has been stored in the glamour dresser, select Apply Glamour from the subcommand menu to glamour your current equipment without spending a glamour prism. Alternatively, select Edit Glamour Plates to bring up the Glamour Plate Creation window, where you can create full sets of glamoured attire that can be applied to your character all at once, using items stored in either the glamour dresser or the armoire.

Created using the glamour dressers found inside inn rooms, glamour plates are a means of projecting an entire ensemble onto your gear. Glamours stored inside a glamour dresser or equipment stored inside an armoire can be projected onto your gear, allowing you to concoct a unique look for your character. Ensembles saved to a glamour plate can be projected over and over again without consuming glamour prisms.

Select Edit Glamour Plates from the glamour dresser window and choose the plate you wish to edit. You can now select a category (head, body, etc.) followed by a glamour stored in the dresser or an item stored in the armoire. Stored items and glamours are not removed after being added to a plate. One you are satisfied with your glamour plate, select the Save button. Items added to glamour plates can also be dyed. This only affects the selected plate─the stored item will retain its original color. Should you wish to remove an item from a plate, select Remove Item Image from Plate. ※It is not necessary to add items to every category. Depending on the style you are trying to achieve, you can simply create a partially filled plate.

Select the Apply button to project the saved ensemble onto your equipped gear. This process does not consume glamour prisms. ※In the event a glamour plate cannot be fully applied, an “X” symbol will be displayed in the corresponding category icons.

Glamour plates can be accessed and used at any time in cities, residential areas, and sanctuaries. Simply select the Glamour Plate button above the character window to view and select a glamour. The window can also be accessed via the General section of the Actions & Traits menu.

You can change the outward appearance of gear sets by linking them to glamour plates. Select the Link to Glamour Plate subcommand from the gear set list to automatically apply the linked glamour plate when switching to the corresponding gear set. ※This feature does not function in instanced areas or outside of large settlements.
Select the Dispel Glamour button in the upper right corner of the Plate Selection window to remove glamours from selected categories. This process consumes glamour dispellers.
Available in inn rooms or placed as furnishings in player estates, armoires are used to store artifact armor, seasonal event costumes, achievement rewards, bonus items, and other specific gear.
To determine whether a given item can be stored in the armoire, navigate to the item help window. If the armoire icon in the upper right corner is lit up, the item can be stored.
Gear with condition below 100% cannot be stored.
Placing an item into the armoire will reset its spiritbond to 0%, as well as remove all customization. However, you may store and withdraw items at no cost.

Once an item has been stored in the armoire, select Apply Glamour from the subcommand menu to glamour your current equipment without spending a glamour prism. Alternatively, items in the armoire can be added to glamour plates without needing to store them in the glamour dresser. Note that any dyes applied to the item will be reset. To preserve existing dyes or add new ones before applying glamours, it is recommended to store the item in the glamour dresser instead.

Crests are sigils representing different free companies that can be applied to applicable gear. To apply a crest to your gear, speak with an OIC officer of arms belonging to the Grand Company your free company is associated with. Crests can be removed at any time. An illuminated crest icon in the top right corner of the item help window indicates that the corresponding piece of gear can have a crest applied to it.

Crest design consists of three basic elements: ・The main emblem, or Charge ・The basic shape, or Escutcheon ・The basic pattern, or Ordinary Use the Crest Customization feature to devise a crest your free company can be proud of.

To design and apply a crest, you must first have risen to a sufficient rank within your free company. ・Crest Customization (Rank 2) gives you the authorization to edit crest designs. ・Gear Customization (Rank 4) gives you the authorization to apply crests to personal gear. ・Crest Expansion (Rank 7) unlocks a range of new crest designs.

Facewear refers to a range of facial accessories that can add extra flourish to an ensemble. Unlike standard gear, facewear is purely decorative.

Facewear is acquired by using the corresponding item. Once acquired, facewear can be worn or removed at any time. To do so, simply select Facewear via the Character tab in the Actions & Traits menu, or click the Facewear icon to the bottom left of the character window. This will display an overview of your registered items.
Select an item of facewear to wear in the Style section, and customize it by choosing a Color.

You can change the color of gear and furnishing items through the use of dyes, with one pot of dye consumed for each distinct section of an item. ※Some items allow for two dye slots. Dyed items can be redyed and undyed any number of times.
Dyeable items have circular symbols in the upper right corner of their icons.

If the circle is empty, as shown on the left, no dye has been applied.

If the circle is filled in, as shown in the center, the item has been dyed with the corresponding color.

If there are no circles, as shown on the right, the item cannot be dyed.
If an item has two dye slots, it will display two circles.

There are many different colors of dyes. If you wish to apply the same color to both sections or multiple items, you will need to ensure you have enough dye for each.

Both dyes and terebinth are available from vendors and the market boards, and can also be crafted by Disciples of the Hand from level 30 onwards.

To use a dye, select Character in the main menu and open the Actions & Traits window, then select the Dye action under the General tab. You can also use this action from the subcommand menu of the item you wish to dye. From the Item Dyeing window, select the desired item from the list, then select the section you wish to dye.
※For items with a single dye slot, Dye 1 will be the only option.
Once you have selected a section, choose your desired color.

Use the colored circles near the top to switch between color categories, then choose your desired dye from the colored squares beneath. Any colors not currently in your possession will be marked with an “X” icon. You may also use the subcommand menu to set favored dyes, enabling you to apply your preferred color scheme to multiple items with ease. Confirm your chosen color settings in the preview pane, then select Dye to begin the process.

Should you wish to restore your gear to its original hue, a pot of terebinth removes the dye from a single section of an item. To use terebinth, select the leftmost square located under the leftmost color category.
Once terebinth has been set to the section you wish to undye, select Dye to begin the dye removal process.
Some items cannot be dyed until you have fulfilled specific conditions, indicated by the lock symbol in the upper right corner.
The requirements for these items can be reviewed at any time from the Item Dyeing window. Once met, the lock icon will change to a circle.
While your retainer is summoned, select Dye Items from the retainer menu to apply dyes to their equipment or any other gear in their possession.

Basics of Combat
Attack Markers
Some enemy attacks will show an indication of where they will strike in the form of a marker. In most cases, you can avoid taking damage by moving outside of the highlighted area before it lands.
These markers take many forms.
Enmity

Enmity is the priority system by which an enemy chooses a target. All players entered into combat with the enemy generate enmity through dealing damage or healing allies.

There are two ways to check your current enmity level:

①The Enmity List
The enmity list shows all enemies with whom you have generated enmity. The icon on the left indicates your current enmity level. The four levels are displayed below in order of greatest to least.

②The Party List
The party list shows each party member's enmity level with the currently selected enemy, as indicated in the lower left corner of the class/job icon.

The player with the greatest enmity is marked with A, followed by 2, 3, and so on. The adjacent gauge shows the relative difference in enmity compared to the player with the most.

During party combat, if you find that the enemies are swarming you instead of the tank, you may wish to withhold your attacks until the tank has regained enmity.

■ Tank Stance
Each tank job has a special action that helps to keep their enmity level high.

With tank stance active, attacks dealt to enemies will generate significantly higher enmity, controlling the focus of enemy attacks and thereby helping to keep allies safe. This is a key aspect of playing as a tank in party combat.
Enhancements and Enfeeblements

An enhancement is a status effect that strengthens the player, whereas an enfeeblement is one that weakens the player. The icons for enhancements and enfeeblements you receive will appear in the Status Effects element of your HUD layout.

Enhancements have icons shaped like upward arrows, whereas enfeeblements are shaped like downward arrows. A white line across the top of the icon indicates that the enfeeblement can be removed with certain healing actions such as Esuna.
Types of Markers
Targeting Markers
This marker indicates that you have been targeted with some manner of attack.
The specifics of the ensuing attack will vary depending on the enemy and/or duty, but in all cases, it will involve you in some way.
Area of Effect Markers
This marker indicates that you have been targeted with an area of effect attack. Targeted players should move away from their allies, and vice versa.
Stack Markers

This marker indicates that a powerful area of effect attack is imminent. As a stack marker is all but impossible to survive alone, it is imperative that the targeted player stand with as many allies as possible to divide the damage evenly.

Note that there are two different types of stack marker:

■ Circle Stack
■ Line Stack
Lethal Attack Markers

This marker warns of an incredibly powerful attack. Typically, it targets the player with the most enmity, and because it deals tremendous damage, most non-tank jobs are unlikely to survive it.

Should you be targeted, your defensive abilities can help keep you safe. For example, tanks can use Rampart to lower damage sustained as well as Reprisal to lower enemy damage output. For all other roles, check the Actions & Traits menu to see which defensive abilities your job can learn.

Note that there are a few different markers, each with different areas of effect:

■ Solo Marker
Depending on the enemy, these may inflict an area of effect attack.
■ Area of Effect Marker

■ Line / Cleave Marker
These attacks will strike the entire area behind the target.

■ Stack Marker
The spheres orbiting the center indicate how many players are needed to withstand the attack.
Homing Area of Effect Markers

This marker indicates that you will be chased by a series of area of effect attacks targeting your current location.

Because these attacks will strike rapidly and repeatedly, the best course of action is to stay on the move, away from your allies.
Knockback Markers

This marker indicates that a knockback attack is imminent. When it strikes, you will be pushed a set distance away from the point of impact based on your relative location. Keep this in mind and either position yourself accordingly or use an action that nullifies knockback effects.

Note that there are different types of knockback:

■ Radial Knockback
Players will be pushed outwards from the point of impact. If the marker is purple, like this one, it cannot be nullified by job actions.

■ Directional Knockback
Players will be pushed in a single set direction.
Area of Effect Knockback Markers

This area of effect marker has an accompanying knockback effect. When it strikes, you will be pushed a set distance away from the point of impact based on your relative location. You will take damage if you stand inside its bounds, so you should position yourself along its outer edges.
If the marker is purple, like this one, it cannot be nullified by job actions.
Flare Markers
This marker indicates that a proximity-based area of effect attack is imminent. The closer you stand to its point of impact, the more damage you will take, so retreat as far as you can.
Sometimes these proximity attacks will target a specific player. To minimize damage, the target should move away from the rest of their party, and vice versa.
Tower Markers
This marker indicates that a tower attack is imminent. If left unoccupied by at least one player, the entire party will take significant damage.

Note that there are different tower markers with different effects:

■ Tank Tower
This type of tower hits especially hard. Only a tank should occupy it.

■ Multi-player Towers
Some towers require a specific number of players to fully absorb the attack. This number will be indicated by the marker. Displayed below are two examples of two-player towers.
Proximity Tether Markers

This spiky marker indicates that you have been tethered to a hostile force. Remain in close proximity and you will receive some manner of negative effect, be it damage or an enfeeblement.

Fortunately, this type of tether can be negated by moving away until the spikes disappear, like so:

Another type of proximity tether, also known as a chain, will continuously damage both players to whom it is connected so long as they remain in close proximity of one another. Affected players can break this tether by moving away from each other.
Interceptible Tether Markers
This marker indicates that an attack will strike the current target. Depending on the situation, it may be necessary for a player to intercept it by physically blocking it from its target.
Gaze Markers

This marker indicates that a gaze attack is imminent. Any player facing the enemy when this attack strikes will receive some manner of negative effect. Alternatively, sometimes the gaze marker will originate from a player instead.

In both cases, it can be negated by facing away from its source before the attack strikes.
Other Markers

Here you will find descriptions of other attack markers encountered in combat.

■ Number Markers
These markers indicate the order in which players will be attacked, starting with the player whose marker has the fewest orbs.

■ Multi-player Markers
This marker indicates the number of players who must stand together to survive the attack, as shown by the number of orbs.

■ Countdown Markers
These markers count down to an imminent attack, and if you are caught doing a forbidden action when it reaches zero, you will be penalized with damage or an enfeeblement.

All countdown markers serve the same function regardless of enemy or duty, and over time you will learn the forbidden actions typically associated with each one.
Playing with Character Voices
About Mahjong Character Voices

By enabling Mahjong Character Voices, one of several characters you've encountered on your adventures can be selected to cheer you on during your matches of mahjong. When in a position to call certain hands, or when match points are tallied, character portraits will display with accompanying voiced lines over the course of the match. ※Characters selected by other players will not be shown.
Character Voice Settings

Character voices can be enabled after acquiring special items purchased from in Wonder Square. ※Players must first complete the main scenario quest “.” Once purchased, you can open the Gold Saucer menu and navigate to the Mahjong tab. Then, under Mahjong Character Voices, you can select your desired character to be used during matches. You may also select what attire will be used in the selected character's portrait, unlocking additional outfits as you progress through the main scenario.
What Are Outfit Glamours?
Creating Outfit Glamours
Outfit Glamour-ready Gear
Items Comprising an Outfit Glamour

Outfit glamours are a means of projecting the appearance of specific item combinations onto an outfit that can be stored in the glamour dresser. Outfits stored in this manner only take up a single glamour slot. As with standard glamours, outfit glamours can be projected onto your gear or added to glamour plates. To create an outfit glamour, you must possess the corresponding combination of items of identical quality, and an equivalent number of glamour prisms.
When opening the glamour dresser, outfit glamour-ready items are identified by the button displayed in the Glamour Creation window.

Selecting this button will open the Outfit Glamour Creation window. Here you can select items from your Inventory and Armory Chest to include in the outfit glamour. Gear with condition below 100% cannot be used to form an outfit glamour. Unlike standard glamours, the color of dyed gear is not transferred to an outfit glamour. ※Outfit glamours can still be dyed after being projected onto gear or added to a glamour plate. When creating an outfit glamour, several items are combined as an ensemble and saved to the glamour dresser.
You can check which items can be combined to form an outfit glamour by selecting the “View Outfit Glamour-ready Items” subcommand of an outfit glamour-ready item.
Item combinations saved as outfit glamours can be viewed under the Outfits tab of the glamour dresser.

In addition to viewing currently saved outfits under this tab, you can also inspect the individual items that form an outfit by selecting the “Inspect Outfit” subcommand. This subcommand is also accessible via each individual item. As with standard glamours, individual items that form part of an outfit glamour are displayed under their corresponding tab in the glamour dresser. These items are identified as such in the corresponding item details window. Restoring an outfit glamour will return each included item to its original form. ※Specific items from an outfit glamour cannot be restored individually.
Cast Bars
Some enemy attacks take time to cast before they strike. A progress bar will appear beside the name of the caster, and once this bar fills completely, the attack will be unleashed.
Note that attacks with no cast time will not display a cast bar.
